headline.main: For Soviet Space Efforts, a Satirist's Send-Down

results.snippet: OMON RA  By Victor Pelevin  Translated by Andrew Bromfield. 154 pages.  Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $21.     The dust jacket on this satirical novel proclaims Viktor Pelevin to be the leading Russian novelist of the post-glasnost era -- post-glasnost...
results.lead_paragraph: OMON RA By Victor Pelevin Translated by Andrew Bromfield. 154 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $21. The dust jacket on this satirical novel proclaims Viktor Pelevin to be the leading Russian novelist of the post-glasnost era -- post-glasnost referring presumably to the time after the fall of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Pelevin is certainly an unusual and strange writer, one with the kind of mordant, astringent turn of mind that in the pre-glasnost era landed writers in psychiatric hospitals or exile. ''Omon Ra,'' a spoof of the Soviet space program and the first of Mr. Pelevin's novels to be translated into English, is not always on target, but when it is, which is quite often, it is wicked, clever and poetic.
